awd_titl_txt: Support for US Early Career Researchers to Present at 25th International Congress of Theoretical & Applied Mechanics (ICTAM); Virtual; August 22-27, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support 60 fellowships for US early career researchers presenting papers at the 25th International Congress of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics, organized under the auspices of the International Union of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics, to be held virtually on August 22-27, 2021. The purpose of this fellowship program is to increase the number of scientists and engineers from U.S. institutions, with an emphasis on graduate students and junior researchers, presenting papers and posters at the aforementioned Congress. One highlight of this program is a unique mentoring experience in the mechanics field, which brings together early career mechanicians, members of the U.S. National Committee for Theoretical and Applied Mechanics, and other senior U.S. mechanicians with extensive leadership experience. The increased involvement of researchers from the U.S. will strengthen U.S. mechanics research enterprise and help build international collaborations and global networks. This award is aligned with the mission of the National Science Foundation and promotes the advancement of science, engineering, and mathematics.  It also fosters research and development in the field of mechanics, which has an impact in innovation, commercialization, and national security. Furthermore, the project seeks to expand the capacity and capability of U.S. early career researchers and has a strong focus on education, professional development, which benefits the U.S. society at large.
 
The fellowship program has the following objectives: 1) support early career U.S. mechanicians in sharing their research at the Congress, 2) enhance engagement of a diverse group of early career researchers, 3) provide opportunities for interaction between U.S. early career scientists and leading U.S. and international mechanicians, 4) provide the fellows with a mentoring experience, 5) expose the fellows to new areas of mechanics research, 6) build a network of early career and senior U.S. mechanicians, 7) foster international collaborations between U.S. mechanicians and their international peers, 8) enhance the communication effectiveness of mechanicians broadly, and 9) initiate an ongoing relationship between early career researchers and the U.S. National Committee for Theoretical and Applied Mechanics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

The U.S. National Committee for Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (USNC/TAM) organized a program to support 60 fellowships for U.S. early career researchers presenting papers at or attending the 25th International Congress of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (ICTAM). This International Congress was organized under the auspices of the International Union of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (IUTAM) and held virtually on August 22-27, 2021 by the Italian mechanician community. The funding for this fellowship program was provided by NSF (Award # 2135969). The purpose of the USNC/TAM fellows program is to increase the number of scientists and engineers from U.S. institutions, with an emphasis on graduate students and junior researchers, presenting papers and posters at ICTAM. The increased involvement of researchers from the U.S. in ICTAM strengthens the U.S. mechanics research enterprise and helps build international collaborations and global networks.

Intellectual Merit

The overarching goal of this program was to increase the number and diversity of scientists and engineers from U.S. institutions presenting papers at or participating in the 25th International Congress of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics (ICTAM 2020+1). The highlights of this program are a mentoring experience prior to the Congress and professional development opportunities before and after the Congress. Early career mechanicians had the opportunity to interact with members of the USNC/TAM and other senior mechanicians with extensive policy and leadership experience. In addition, a virtual Mentoring Event was held prior to the Congress where fellows met with each other and with the mentors, and learned from an expert in the mechanics field how to optimize mentoring. The program:

  1. Increased the number of U.S. early career mechanicians sharing their research and interacting with other top international peers
  2. Increased the number of interactions between early and senior career mechanicians
  3. Provided fellows with mentors and peer colleagues with which to interact at the Congress
  4. Increased the fellows’ level of knowledge on a diverse set of mechanics topics
  5. Built a network of early career and senior U.S. mechanicians
  6. Promoted international collaborations at Congress activities. 

Broader Impact

The USNC/TAM made a great effort to get a diverse pool of applicants and placed special emphasis on outreach to underrepresented groups. The opportunity was widely announced by advertising it on the USNC/TAM newsletter and website, professional societies, iMechanica.org, NSF and NAS listservs, and selected distribution lists to reach underrepresented minority groups. A selection subcommittee of the USNC/TAM was formed and reviewed the applications: Yuri Bazilevs, Professor, Brown University; Samantha Daly, Professor, University of California - Santa Barbara;

Anne Grillet, Distinguished Member of Technical Staff, Sandia National Laboratories; and Yong Zhu, Professor, North Carolina State University. The group of experts selected the awardees according to established criteria designed to prioritize diversity and enable early career researchers in mechanics to attend the Congress who may not otherwise be able to do so.

Overall and in terms of diversity, 12% were female and 11% from underrepresented minority groups. Fifty-four came from academia, one from industry, and two from government/national laboratories, and the rest from others. Among the participants from academia, 7% were from non-R1 institutions. Four percent of the fellows requested and received childcare support in order to participate in the Congress. For 87% percent of the fellows, this was the first time participating in an IUTAM Congress. Forty-four percent of the fellows were graduate students, 32% were post-docs/adjunct professor/lecturers, and 24% were assistant professors. Most of them found out about this opportunity through email announcement or through their major professors. Around 60 percent of fellows will participate in the next congress in 2023 in Korea, and 35 percent might attend.
